Consistent with the strong relationship between wealth, energy consumption, and CO 2 emissions ( 24 – 26), we also find a positive relationship between per capita cumulative emissions and impact from historical global warming ( Fig. 3 C and
SI Appendix, Fig. S1 ). For example, over the 1961–2010 period, all 18 of the countries whose historical cumulative emissions are less than 10 ton CO 2 per capita have suffered negative economic impacts, with a median impact of −27% (relative to a world without anthropogenic forcing) ( Fig. 3 C ). Likewise, of the 36 countries whose historical emissions are between 10 and 100 ton CO 2 per capita, 34 (94%) have suffered negative economic impacts, with a median impact of −24%. In contrast, of the 19 countries whose historical emissions exceed 300 ton CO 2 per capita, 14 (74%) have benefited from global warming, with a median benefit across those 14 countries of +13%.
